title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 8 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Corinthians chapter 8 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 8 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Corinthians Chapter 8.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:1, on whom was the grace of God bestowed?
questions.correctAnswer: The churches of Macedonia
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Corinthians 8:1 states that the grace of God was bestowed on the churches of Macedonia.

questions.question: What characterized the churches of Macedonia during their great trial, as mentioned in 2 Corinthians 8:2?
options: Abundance of joy and deep poverty
questions.correctAnswer: Abundance of joy and deep poverty
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 8:2 describes how, in a great trial of affliction, their abundance of joy and deep poverty abounded unto the riches of their liberality.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 8:3, the Macedonians gave beyond their power willingly.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Corinthians 8:3 confirms that the Macedonians were willing to give beyond their power.

questions.question: Who did the Macedonians urge to receive the gift and participate in ministering to the saints? (2 Corinthians 8:4)
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and his companions
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 8:4, the Macedonians prayed much that Paul and his companions would receive the gift and take part in the fellowship of ministering to the saints.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:5, what did the Macedonians give first?
options: Their own selves to the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Their own selves to the Lord
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 8:5 explains that the Macedonians first gave themselves to the Lord and to Paul by the will of God.

questions.question: What did Paul desire Titus to do, according to 2 Corinthians 8:6?
options: Finish the grace in the Corinthians
Write a letter to the churches
questions.correctAnswer: Finish the grace in the Corinthians
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Corinthians 8:6 states that Paul desired Titus to complete the grace that had begun in the Corinthians.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:7, in which areas are the Corinthians abounding?
options: Faith, utterance, knowledge, diligence, and love
questions.correctAnswer: Faith, utterance, knowledge, diligence, and love
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 8:7 lists these qualities as areas where the Corinthians abound and encourages them to also abound in grace.

questions.question: True or False: In 2 Corinthians 8:8, Paul speaks by commandment regarding giving.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 8:8 clarifies that Paul does not speak by commandment but by occasion of the forwardness of others.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:9, why did Jesus Christ become poor?
options: So that through His poverty people might be rich
questions.correctAnswer: So that through His poverty people might be rich
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Corinthians 8:9 explains that though Jesus was rich, He became poor so that through His poverty others might become rich.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 8:10, Paul advises the Corinthians to be what regarding their giving?
questions.correctAnswer: Forward and willing
questions.explanation: Paul advises in 2 Corinthians 8:10 that the Corinthians should be forward in giving, building on their previous readiness.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 8:12, God accepts giving based on what a person has, not what they do not have.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 8:12 states that if there is a willing mind, it is accepted according to what a person has.

questions.question: What is the principle of giving described in 2 Corinthians 8:14?
options: Equality in supply between abundance and want
questions.correctAnswer: Equality in supply between abundance and want
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Corinthians 8:14 teaches that abundance should supply for want so that there is equality among believers.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Corinthians 8:15: 'He that had gathered much had ______; and he that had gathered little had no lack.'
questions.correctAnswer: nothing over
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 8:15 states that he who gathered much had nothing over, emphasizing fairness in giving.

questions.question: Who was sent with Titus as a praised brother in the gospel, according to 2 Corinthians 8:18?
options: A brother whose praise is throughout all the churches
questions.correctAnswer: A brother whose praise is throughout all the churches
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 8:18 mentions that a brother praised in the gospel throughout all churches was sent with Titus.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:20, what is the purpose of administering the abundance?
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid blame
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Corinthians 8:20 states that the abundance is administered to avoid blame in the process.

medium.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 8 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Corinthians Chapter 8 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 8 teach us about generosity in the midst of personal hardship?
questions.correctAnswer: Joyful giving even in poverty
questions.explanation: Verse 2 shows that despite deep poverty, the Macedonian churches abounded in liberality and joy, teaching that generosity is possible and commendable even in hardship. See also verses 1, 3, and 4 for God's grace empowering such giving.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8, what is the proper attitude toward giving?
questions.correctAnswer: Willingness and self-initiative
questions.explanation: Verse 3 highlights that the Macedonians gave beyond their power, and of their own accord, emphasizing willingness rather than compulsion. Verses 8, 11, and 12 also reinforce giving from the heart and according to one's means.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 8:9 teach us about Christ's example in generosity?
options: Christ became poor so we might be rich
Christ remained rich and gave generously
Christ taught to save wealth for oneself
questions.correctAnswer: Christ became poor so we might be rich
questions.explanation: Verse 9 clearly states that though Christ was rich, He became poor for our sakes so that through His poverty we might become rich, illustrating the ultimate example of sacrificial giving and humility. See also verses 7 and 10 for encouragement to abound in grace.

questions.question: If a believer desires to give but has limited resources, how does 2 Corinthians 8 advise them?
options: Giving according to what one has
Giving only after others have given more
Giving less than others to avoid burden
questions.correctAnswer: Giving according to what one has
questions.explanation: Verse 12 teaches that a willing mind is accepted according to what a person has, not according to what they do not have, encouraging giving within one's means. This is consistent with the theme of willingness in verses 3, 8, and 11.

questions.question: What biblical principle about fairness and equality in giving is taught in 2 Corinthians 8?
options: Sharing so that abundance meets need
Giving only to those who can give back
questions.correctAnswer: Sharing so that abundance meets need
questions.explanation: Verses 13 and 14 emphasize that giving should be done so there is equality: those with abundance supply the needs of others, and vice versa. This reflects mutual care and fairness among believers.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 8 encourage believers to demonstrate sincerity in their love through giving?
options: By proving sincerity through generous giving
By giving secretly to avoid recognition
By giving to gain approval from others
questions.correctAnswer: By proving sincerity through generous giving
questions.explanation: Verse 8 explains that Paul speaks to prove the sincerity of their love, indicating that genuine love is demonstrated through willing and generous giving. This is echoed in verses 7 and 24 regarding love and proof of love.

questions.question: What role did Titus play in the ministry of generosity according to 2 Corinthians 8?
options: He was a partner and helper in encouraging giving
He discouraged giving to save money
He only collected money without encouragement
He opposed the collection of gifts
questions.correctAnswer: He was a partner and helper in encouraging giving
questions.explanation: Verses 6, 22, and 23 show that Titus was a trusted partner and fellow helper who was diligent and had great confidence in the Corinthians, encouraging them to complete their act of grace.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 8, the giving of the Macedonian churches was less than Paul expected.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states that the Macedonians gave not as Paul hoped, but even more—they first gave themselves to the Lord, surpassing expectations. This shows their exemplary generosity and dedication.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 8 teaches that performing acts of giving should be done only when there is a commandment.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 8 clarifies that Paul does not speak by commandment but by occasion and to prove sincerity, indicating that giving should come from the heart, not solely from obligation. This is supported by verses 3 and 12.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with feeling inadequate in their giving. Based on 2 Corinthians 8, what biblical truth can you share?
options: God accepts a willing heart according to ability
Only large gifts are valuable to God
Giving is only for the wealthy
One should wait until having more resources
questions.correctAnswer: God accepts a willing heart according to ability
questions.explanation: Verse 12 teaches that a willing mind is accepted according to what one has, not what one does not have, encouraging believers to give according to their means with a willing heart. See also verses 3 and 11.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 8 instruct the church regarding honesty and integrity in handling gifts?
options: To provide for honest things in sight of God and men
To hide the giving process from others
To only report giving to church leaders
questions.correctAnswer: To provide for honest things in sight of God and men
questions.explanation: Verse 21 teaches that those administering the gifts must act honestly before both God and people, emphasizing integrity and transparency. This is supported by verses 20 and 22 regarding avoiding blame and diligence.

questions.question: When believers abound in faith, knowledge, and love, what else does 2 Corinthians 8 encourage them to abound in?
questions.correctAnswer: Grace of giving
questions.explanation: Verse 7 encourages believers to abound not only in faith, utterance, knowledge, diligence, and love but also in the grace of giving, highlighting generosity as a spiritual virtue. This is linked to verses 1 and 9.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'He that had gathered much had ________; and he that had gathered little had no lack.'
questions.correctAnswer: nothing over
questions.explanation: Verse 15 quotes Scripture teaching equality in provision, with those who gathered much having nothing left over and those with little lacking nothing, emphasizing mutual support and balance.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 8 say about the motivation behind sending brothers like the one praised in the gospel with Titus?
options: To administer the grace for the Lord’s glory and to demonstrate readiness
To collect as much money as possible regardless of motive
To impose giving on churches by force
To gain personal recognition for the leaders
questions.correctAnswer: To administer the grace for the Lord’s glory and to demonstrate readiness
questions.explanation: Verses 18 and 19 explain that such brothers were chosen to travel with Paul to administer the grace given, to glorify the Lord, and to declare the readiness of the churches, highlighting God-honoring motives.

questions.question: How should believers demonstrate the proof of their love and Paul’s boasting on their behalf according to 2 Corinthians 8?
options: By showing generosity before the churches
By only verbally affirming their love
questions.correctAnswer: By showing generosity before the churches
questions.explanation: Verse 24 instructs believers to show proof of their love and Paul’s boasting before the churches, meaning their generosity and commitment should be evident publicly as a testimony.

hard.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 8 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Corinthians Chapter 8.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:2, how did the Macedonian churches respond to their great trial of affliction?
options: Their joy abounded despite deep poverty
questions.correctAnswer: Their joy abounded despite deep poverty
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 8:2 explains that in a great trial of affliction, the abundance of their joy and their deep poverty abounded unto the riches of their liberality, showing their joyful generosity despite hardship.

questions.question: What does Paul emphasize about the Macedonians' giving in 2 Corinthians 8:3?
options: They gave beyond their power willingly
They gave only what was commanded
questions.correctAnswer: They gave beyond their power willingly
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 8:3 states that the Macedonians were willing of themselves to give beyond their power, highlighting their voluntary and generous spirit.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 8:5, what is said about the Macedonians' first commitment before their giving?
options: They first gave themselves to the Lord and to Paul by the will of God
They gave only money but not themselves
questions.correctAnswer: They first gave themselves to the Lord and to Paul by the will of God
questions.explanation: Verse 5 emphasizes that the Macedonians gave themselves first to the Lord and to Paul according to God’s will, indicating total dedication prior to their material generosity.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:7, in addition to faith and knowledge, what else are the Corinthians urged to abound in?
questions.correctAnswer: Love and diligence
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 8:7 instructs the Corinthians to abound in faith, utterance, knowledge, diligence, and in their love to Paul, showing a comprehensive spiritual growth.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Paul’s encouragement in 2 Corinthians 8:8 regarding their giving?
options: To prove the sincerity of their love
questions.correctAnswer: To prove the sincerity of their love
questions.explanation: Paul states in verse 8 that he speaks not by commandment but to prove the sincerity of their love, indicating the voluntary nature of true generosity.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 8:9, what theological truth is highlighted about Jesus Christ’s incarnation and sacrifice?
options: Though rich, He became poor so we might be rich
He remained rich to bless the poor
He avoided poverty by divine power
He only appeared to be poor
questions.correctAnswer: Though rich, He became poor so we might be rich
questions.explanation: Verse 9 reveals the profound grace of Christ who, though rich, became poor for our sakes, so that through His poverty we might be made rich, highlighting the substitutionary nature of His sacrifice.

questions.question: What does Paul advise in 2 Corinthians 8:10-11 regarding the Corinthians' giving?
options: To complete their commitment with action
To delay giving until next year
To give secretly without others knowing
questions.correctAnswer: To complete their commitment with action
questions.explanation: Paul advises in verses 10 and 11 that since they began a year before, they should now perform the doing to match their readiness to will, emphasizing completion and follow-through.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:12, how is a willing mind viewed in the context of giving?
options: It is accepted according to what one has
It must be judged by the amount given
It is only accepted if publicly declared
questions.correctAnswer: It is accepted according to what one has
questions.explanation: Verse 12 teaches that God accepts a willing mind according to what a person has, not what they do not have, emphasizing the value of intention over quantity.

questions.question: What principle of giving is taught in 2 Corinthians 8:13-14 regarding equality?
options: Sharing so that abundance supplies want and vice versa
Giving only when others are burdened
Avoiding giving to those in need
Keeping wealth strictly for personal use
questions.correctAnswer: Sharing so that abundance supplies want and vice versa
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 emphasize equality in giving, where those with abundance supply the needs of others, fostering mutual support and balance among believers.

questions.question: The quotation in 2 Corinthians 8:15, "He that had gathered much had nothing over; and he that had gathered little had no lack," is an allusion to which Old Testament event?
options: The manna provision in the wilderness
The crossing of the Red Sea
The giving of the Ten Commandments
questions.correctAnswer: The manna provision in the wilderness
questions.explanation: The verse alludes to Exodus 16:18, where manna was gathered daily and none had excess or deficiency, illustrating God's provision and the principle of equitable sharing.

questions.question: Who is described in 2 Corinthians 8:16 as having earnest care put into their heart by God for the Corinthians?
questions.correctAnswer: Titus
questions.explanation: Verse 16 thanks God for putting earnest care into Titus’s heart for the Corinthians, highlighting his faithful ministry and concern.

questions.question: What is the purpose of sending the brother praised in the gospel with Titus, according to 2 Corinthians 8:18-19?
options: To administer the grace and to declare the Corinthians’ readiness
To collect taxes from the churches
To impose strict rules on giving
questions.correctAnswer: To administer the grace and to declare the Corinthians’ readiness
questions.explanation: Verses 18-19 explain the brother was sent to assist in administering the grace and to declare the Corinthians’ readiness to give, ensuring transparency and accountability.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:20-21, why does Paul emphasize providing for honest things in sight of both God and men?
options: To avoid blame and maintain integrity
To increase wealth for the apostles
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid blame and maintain integrity
questions.explanation: Paul stresses in these verses the importance of integrity so that no one can blame them in administering the abundance, highlighting accountability before God and humans.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 8:23, who are described as 'the messengers of the churches, and the glory of Christ'?
options: The brethren sent with Paul and Titus
questions.correctAnswer: The brethren sent with Paul and Titus
questions.explanation: Verse 23 identifies the brethren accompanying Paul and Titus as messengers of the churches and the glory of Christ, reflecting their honored role in the early church.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 8:9, Jesus Christ’s becoming poor was to make others spiritually rich.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states that though Jesus was rich, He became poor for our sakes so that we through His poverty might be rich, denoting spiritual enrichment through His sacrifice.

theological.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 8 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Corinthians Chapter 8 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:1-2, how did the Macedonian churches exemplify the grace of God in their giving?
options: They gave abundantly despite great affliction and poverty
They gave only after receiving abundant wealth
They refused to give due to their poverty
They gave without any trial or affliction
questions.correctAnswer: They gave abundantly despite great affliction and poverty
questions.explanation: Verses 1 and 2 explain that the Macedonians experienced great trials and deep poverty, yet their joy abounded and their liberality overflowed. This reflects God's grace working in their lives, consistent with 2 Corinthians 9:7 and Exodus 35:21 where giving is according to the heart despite circumstances.

questions.question: What motivated the Macedonians to give generously according to 2 Corinthians 8:3-5?
options: They first gave themselves to the Lord and to the apostles
They were commanded by Paul to give
They gave reluctantly but out of obligation
They sought praise from others for their giving
questions.correctAnswer: They first gave themselves to the Lord and to the apostles
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states their giving was preceded by giving themselves to the Lord and to Paul by the will of God, showing their spiritual commitment and voluntary generosity. This aligns with Romans 12:1 and Luke 21:1-4 emphasizing wholehearted devotion prior to material giving.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 8:7, Paul exhorts the Corinthians to abound in grace just as they abound in other qualities. Which qualities are mentioned?
options: Faith, utterance, knowledge, diligence, and love
questions.correctAnswer: Faith, utterance, knowledge, diligence, and love
questions.explanation: Paul lists these qualities to encourage them to excel in grace as well, indicating the holistic nature of Christian maturity (1 Corinthians 13:13; Galatians 5:22-23; Colossians 3:12).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:9, why did Jesus Christ become poor?
options: So that through His poverty we might become rich
To set an example of humility
Because He was rejected by the world
questions.correctAnswer: So that through His poverty we might become rich
questions.explanation: The verse reveals the substitutionary nature of Christ's incarnation and poverty, granting spiritual riches to believers. This ties to Isaiah 53:3-5, Philippians 2:6-8, and 1 Timothy 6:6-8 emphasizing Christ's humility for our redemption.

questions.question: What principle does Paul teach in 2 Corinthians 8:12 regarding the acceptance of a gift?
options: God accepts a gift according to what one has, not what one does not have
Only large gifts are acceptable to God
Gifts are accepted only if they are given publicly
Giving is irrelevant if the heart is not pure
questions.correctAnswer: God accepts a gift according to what one has, not what one does not have
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes the importance of willingness over abundance, similar to the widow’s offering in Mark 12:41-44 and Exodus 35:21, teaching that God values the heart and proportionate giving.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the equality Paul describes in 2 Corinthians 8:14?
options: To ensure that abundance in one community supplies the needs of another, establishing fairness
To create a hierarchy of giving between rich and poor
To mandate equal monetary amounts from all believers
questions.correctAnswer: To ensure that abundance in one community supplies the needs of another, establishing fairness
questions.explanation: Paul’s teaching on equality fosters mutual care and solidarity among believers, reflecting principles in Acts 2:44-45 and Leviticus 25:35 about sharing resources and caring for the needy.

questions.question: Who is commended for his earnest care and forwardness in 2 Corinthians 8:16-17?
questions.correctAnswer: Titus
questions.explanation: Titus is praised for his dedicated concern and voluntary service, illustrating faithful leadership and partnership in ministry, consistent with Paul's commendations in Titus 1:5 and 2 Corinthians 12:18.

questions.question: What was the role of the brother sent with Titus according to 2 Corinthians 8:18-19?
options: He was praised throughout the churches and chosen to administer the grace of giving
He was a military escort to protect the gift
He was a scribe to record the transactions
He was a critic sent to ensure correct giving
questions.correctAnswer: He was praised throughout the churches and chosen to administer the grace of giving
questions.explanation: This brother’s trusted role highlights accountability and transparency in ministry, aligned with biblical principles in Acts 6:3-6 and 1 Timothy 3:8-13 regarding church leadership and stewardship.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:20-21, why is it important to provide for honest things both in the sight of the Lord and men?
options: To avoid any blame and maintain integrity
To gain human approval and praise
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid any blame and maintain integrity
questions.explanation: Paul underscores integrity in ministry to prevent accusations, reflecting biblical calls for blamelessness as in Philippians 2:15, 1 Timothy 3:2, and Proverbs 10:9, demonstrating faithful witness before God and people.

questions.question: What confidence does Paul express in 2 Corinthians 8:22 concerning the brother sent with Titus?
options: He is diligent and trustworthy in many things
He is a newcomer to ministry
questions.correctAnswer: He is diligent and trustworthy in many things
questions.explanation: Paul’s confidence highlights the brother’s proven faithfulness, paralleling qualities praised in faithful servants in Proverbs 12:24 and Luke 16:10, essential in stewardship and leadership.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the relationship between Titus and himself in 2 Corinthians 8:23?
options: Titus is Paul's partner and fellow helper concerning the Corinthians
Titus is a subordinate under Paul’s authority
questions.correctAnswer: Titus is Paul's partner and fellow helper concerning the Corinthians
questions.explanation: This partnership reflects shared ministry and mutual support, consistent with biblical teamwork models like Paul and Barnabas (Acts 13:2-3) and Jesus sending disciples in unity (John 17:21).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 8:24, what should the churches demonstrate to Titus and the other messengers?
options: The proof of their love and Paul's boasting on their behalf
questions.correctAnswer: The proof of their love and Paul's boasting on their behalf
questions.explanation: Paul desires visible evidence of genuine love and faithfulness, emphasizing accountability and authentic Christian fellowship, in line with 1 John 3:18 and James 2:14-17.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 8:8, what is Paul's purpose in urging the Corinthians to give generously?
options: To prove the sincerity of their love
To gain favor with Roman authorities
questions.correctAnswer: To prove the sincerity of their love
questions.explanation: Paul appeals to love as the motivation, not legal obligation, consistent with the New Testament emphasis on love as the fulfillment of the law (Romans 13:10; Galatians 5:6).

questions.question: What advice does Paul give in 2 Corinthians 8:10-11 to those who began giving previously?
options: To complete what they began by performing the giving
To stop giving and wait for further instruction
To give secretly without others knowing
questions.correctAnswer: To complete what they began by performing the giving
questions.explanation: Paul encourages follow-through on commitments, highlighting the importance of integrity and action in Christian life (James 2:17; Luke 16:10).

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 8:13 clarify about the burden of giving among different groups?
options: Other men should not be eased while others are burdened
The poor should give more than the rich
All should give equally regardless of means
Giving is optional for the wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: Other men should not be eased while others are burdened
questions.explanation: Paul teaches fairness and mutual support without overburdening any group, reflecting biblical justice and charity principles in Leviticus 19:18 and Matthew 22:39.
